Fields.DialogueText: Bonjour, Capitaine! You wanted to see me? Is this about the visitor from HQ, peut-être?
Yes, actually. They were here about your broadcasts. It seems you have a reputation as a Belle who knows how to communicate with people now.
I certainly like to think that way, Capitaine. Speaking to the sailors, to the civilians, giving them hope; it gives me hope in turn.
Well, let's see if you can bring a little hope to this new task. HQ wants you to develop a new encryption method for our radio communications.
Excusez-moi? Capitaine, I know nothing of radio encryption or any such things.
That's what I said, but apparently taking it upon yourself to produce counterpropaganda to fight back against Despair convinced some people otherwise.
Well, I won't refuse orders, but this is ridiculous!

Fields.MenuText: You know how it is. Nothing gets you more work quite like good work.
This reminds me of a joke I overhead from one of the sailors. Do you know what Navy stands for? Never Again Volunteer Yourself.
It'll be fine, Triomphant. We'll work it out together.

Fields.DialogueText: Hmph. This certainly explains the sheer amount of assignments we get.
I'm not sure whether I should laugh or be disheartened at such a dispiriting joke.
I thank you for your support, Capitaine.
*ALARM*
Well, this at least is a situation I know how to handle! Come, Capitaine!
@BATTLE
J'en ai ras le bol! Capitaine! I cannot take any more of these horrible code books! This is simply madness to ask of us.
Come on, Triomphant, we've only been going over old codes for an hour.
An hour is more than enough for me to know when I am unequal to a task.
*ALARM*
Is it bad that I am happy to see the enemy?
@BATTLE
Sigh... back to this work, then.

Fields.MenuText: Look, we're clearly not getting anywhere with just codes. We need to get books at a higher level.
Can any of the radio techs help us?
What if we came up with a solution that played more to your strengths?

Fields.DialogueText: Yes... perhaps if we study the theory we shall find the rhythms we need.
I shall ask the radio department, and perhaps our intelligence officer. They might use cryptography, but using it is not the same as building it.
Like what? Capitaine, I'm glad you're being supportive, but we must think practically about this.
I'll go and see what I can dig up. Care to join me for the next meal? No cryptologic talk allowed.
Sure, sounds fine to me.
Je te verrai plus tard!
I am afraid, Capitaine, that my project will have to wait.
Why? Oh, Morganas. I am afraid you are right, Triomphant.
@BATTLE
I managed to secure some old theory books on cryptology, but if I am honest... I do not think they will help.
Why's that?
These things are not exactly part of my knowledge base, but I know innately the codes that the INPF and La Royale use. These books are very out of date.
You'd think they'd realize that this type of stuff is pretty classified and they'd need to give us more to go on than just "figure it out".

Fields.MenuText: I don't like it, but should we tell INPF we can't do it?
We're clearly missing something here.
If we keep worrying at it like a dog with a bone we're only going to drive ourselves to distraction.

Fields.DialogueText: Non! I mean... perhaps. I don't want to give up now, though.
Yes... but what? Ooh, this is frustrating! But it makes me want to defeat this foe all the more!
You are right... we should see to our other duties, then take a break. I have a lovely brie and some other snacks. Join me after the next change of watch?
I'd be delighted.
That's the spirit!
That's why we're going to win.
Ah, Triomphant, good. I was just looking for you.
About our little project... I think we need to start thinking outside the box.
Oui. I agree I have not gotten any further with conventional solutions, but it strikes me that a conventional solution is counterproductive for encryption anyway.

Fields.MenuText: Hmm, something musical perhaps? That can be broadcast, and can't even be translated without a code book.
A new form of Morse code or tap code, maybe?
What about something... linguistic? Like a language that isn't commonly spoken or understood?

Fields.DialogueText: Yes... that has possibilities, but it must be easy to transmit, distinguishable to the ear... we should keep that in mind.
Simple, but they tend not to translate terribly quickly without extensive training.
Hmmm. That is an interesting possibility indeed.
I really have to wonder why in the hell they tossed this stuff onto our plate. Radio is one thing, but this...
Ours is not to reason why, Capitaine. We must simply do everything we can for the war effort.
Regardless, we need to continue investigating. I think we might have some interesting leads before us now!
Capitaine?
I see them.
@BATTLE
Capitaine! A moment, please! Sailor, please, tell the Capitaine what you told me.
Yes ma'am. Captain, I grew up in Oklahoma before I joined the Merchant Marines. I overheard Mademoiselle Triomphant talking to one of the radiomen about language on the radio.
Well sir, an Indian gent who lived up the road, Mr. Frazier, he served in the Great War. He told some of us kids about talking on the radio in Choctaw, the language of his tribe.
He said that Jerry- er, the Germans- never even came close to figuring out Choctaw or breaking their code. They couldn't make heads or tails of it.
Apparently they had to make some linguistic leaps to communicate certain things, but c'est très excitant, non? There are many possibilities!

Fields.MenuText: Hmm... but where the heck are we going to find a bunch of Choctaws and convince them to volunteer for the INPF?
You know there's probably a lot of groups like that we could potentially access.
Morgana seem like they can communicate in most languages... we might need to run some tests here.

Fields.DialogueText: That's something we can likely work out with cooperation from the American government.
Yes, I should do some research on such languages. Perhaps one of the other Belles can help.
That... is a possible complication, certainly. A non-verbal code entirely might be our only saving grace.
*ALARM*
We'll continue this later. Action stations!
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Morganas inbound! To your stations!
@BATTLE
Capitaine! Viens à moi, Capitaine!
What is it, Triomphant? You look rather excited.
Oui! Very much so, Capitaine! I believe I have another way to sell these language-based codes to HQ. I believe it could reduce the number of translators we need on each ship.

Fields.MenuText: What? How?
Standardizing the code language.
An example of spending money to make money, to be sure.

Fields.DialogueText: By reducing the number of languages we communicate in to one, we only need translators for the standardized communication language.
Exactement! That way we only need a native speaker and a translator for the captain in question.
Well, yes, but it has many benefits, and that is the message I must sell to headquarters to get them to endorse our plan.
I must say I was not looking forward to this task when it was assigned to us, but the challenge has become somewhat interesting.
If we can make it work, then we'll be able to save a fair few lives.
Which makes it all the more valuable to me personally.
I'm glad you're keeping your spirits up. If you start feeling down, I think we're all lost.
Worry not, Capitaine. Not even the cruelest Morgana can dampen my spirits, and I shall guide us all to victory!
Over the Morgana? Or over the clerk at HQ who assigned us this cryptography job?
Both, of course. With pleasure.
You know, Triomphant, I've been thinking... how many people who can speak our theoretical code language would we need on each ship?
I... hmm. I suppose at least two, non? Because it's not so simple as opening up a code book, so we ought to have a primary code talker and a backup.
Plus a couple of backups available on the flagship and back at headquarters. That way replacements can be sent out and multiple communications can be made.
Perhaps this solution is slightly less practical than I had previously hoped.

Fields.MenuText: Still, the American army seemed to make it work pretty well during the Great War.
We should keep going, if only for the sake of exhausting all our options.
Maybe we should go back to the drawing board.

Fields.DialogueText: Oui, they did. Hmm. Clearly they managed to make things work out, but perhaps it's easier for ground troops than naval forces in some sense.
I hate the idea of giving up, Capitaine, so I'm glad to hear you wish to continue the fight.
Non... I think we must continue, but I am starting to feel that that shall be our fate.
Ah... I am feeling... almost as if I am despairing of completing this task. This is not right; it is not who I am! I must rededicate myself to our task!
Glad to see you keeping your own spirits up. No worries, Triomphant. Even if this doesn't work out, a setback is just another obstacle.
And we shall crush our obstacles! No one can stop us together, Capitaine!
That's the spirit, though that sounds a bit more appropriate for engaging the enemy than writing an encryption scheme.
If it leads to the final defeat of the enemy, a code is a weapon like any other.
*ALARM*
Speaking of which...
@BATTLE
Monsieur, please! I just need to...
Miss, I have told you once, I have told you again, and now I shall tell you a third and final time. First and foremost, the matters you're asking about are classified.
Second, even if they weren't, they represent efforts and resources critical to the defense and interests of the United States. Resources we are not about to share with anyone.
The United States is contributing vast amounts of ships, materiel, and volunteers to the INPF. You coming and demanding more is not conducive to furthering that working relationship.
Good day, Miss. Excuse me, Captain.
Well, he seemed pretty pissed off.
Apparently the Americans do not like questions being asked about these Native languages in connection to the military. The officer seemed shocked I knew at all.
I suppose we should have seen that coming. I wonder if there's other options for us to explore in terms of isolated language groups.

Fields.MenuText: I'll back your choice no matter what on this, Triomphant. Just tell me what you want us to do.
I can go and talk to the INPF high command, or appeal to the US Navy directly.
Seems like we might be chasing shadows somewhat. How many tribes without written languages can there really be with the numbers we'd need?

Fields.DialogueText: I'm not sure where I can even begin, Capitaine!
Hmm... if you'd be willing to do so, I'd appreciate it, but I doubt we'll get much further than with that officer who just left.
Even if we did propose it to another government - and I have no doubt the Americans would be furious if we did - they'd likely decide to keep that strategic resource to themselves as well.
I think we need to approach things from another angle. I'm not giving up, but I want to finish running the numbers before we try something else.
*ALARM*
Right after I let off some steam with these Morganas.
Damn it. Come on!
@BATTLE
Capitaine, there are Morganas due east of us.
Get above and sound the alarm.
@BATTLE
Ah, Triomphant... hey, are you okay? You look a bit glum, and with you, that's extremely worrying.
Capitaine, I have done all I could. I do not think our plan is practical. Perhaps for a local command, but...
Not for an entire Navy. I figured that might be the case. So what did you find?
Well, the Americans are still flatly refusing to speak to me on this subject, but I also looked at the numbers.
US census data is hard to get, but I spoke with some of the sailors. They tell me many of the American tribes are not extremely large populations.
Even using our lowest numbers, I doubt we could supply the fleet with native speakers with just military-age males.
Even if we recruit women as well, as we should... I doubt we'll get enough of any one language to staff the entire INPF.

Fields.MenuText: I suppose we could put a bulletin out suggesting local commanders employ native languages in their areas of operation.
Damn, I thought for sure that this would be the solution.
Good work, Triomphant. You did your best and ran down all the leads. No one can expect more.

Fields.DialogueText: Oui. It might find a use for individual commands, but it simply won't do for the entire fleet.
I did as well, but we must find another path.
Good work? But I fail... no, I see your point. Thank you for buoying my spirits.
Well, triumph never comes without hardship, non?
Exactly right. So let's get back to it.
Capitaine, I brought you some... oh, my. What's all this?
They're called books, they contain printed information that one can study via a process called "reading."
Sarcasm is unbecoming of you, mon ami.
Sorry, I just don't have much patience for this stuff. I'm trying to dig through some of these cryptography books you found and find some sort of lead.
I thank you for shouldering this burden, Capitaine, but you need not do this alone. Have you found anything?

Fields.MenuText: A headache. I've found a headache.
I found out that I'm a far better captain than I am a cryptographer.
That I'm not terribly good at math.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, drink some of this wine. It will hopefully ease your mind.
Luckily you are employed as a capitaine, and there is much call for a capitaine's skills.
Non, dis que ce n'est pas le cas! To think my Capitaine would not have a head for numbers.
Here, bunch up and we'll tackle this together. It surely cannot withstand the both of us.
From your lips to God's ears.
I guess it's time for research.
Come on, Morganas. I've got a hot cup of coffee and everything. You can't convince me you're not going to attack just as I'm-
*ALARM*
There we go.
@BATTLE
You know, I feel like the enemy has been a bit too... accommodating recently.
I really wish you hadn't said that, but what do you mean?
We have not seen more than the usual raids and attacks recently. Nothing major.
*ALARM*
You just had to say something.
@BATTLE
An entire convoy lost! Zut alors! Foul creatures.

Fields.MenuText: I wonder if a failure in cryptography revealed their route to the Morganas.
Damn it all to hell! We should have been faster.
We'll need to advise command to change up the escort patterns. Seems this region's getting hotter.

Fields.DialogueText: Possibly. It could explain why command is so keen for us develop a new code.
I agree. We must be more vigilant in pursuing our true task. Codes might be another sword in the armory, but we must wield what we have.
We shall cool it down again! If we sink these terrors, they cannot harm the people.
We may be going about this whole thing the wrong way. We received this assignment because of how I tackled Despair.
That's true. Convention is probably not what they're looking for. Nothing predictable or easy to decipher.
My thoughts exactly. Hmm... come. Let us have a light repast. I need to think, and I would enjoy your company, mon ami.
Capitaine! Je l'ai compris! I understand where we were going wrong!
Well, don't keep me in suspense.
I must do this my way. Not using the normal tools of cryptography, not even using things that have been done before like language codes.
What I believe in the most is to inspire people, to give them courage, that we might share in victory together.
Music has a place in my heart for this reason. It's always been important to soldiers and sailors, and people in general. What if I can inspire with music while transmitting orders?

Fields.MenuText: You can do that? This I have to see.
Sounds brilliant to me. What do you need?
You really think you can pull that off?

Fields.DialogueText: Hmph. You don't have to sound quite that incredulous.
I'll have the requisition list for the testing equipment ready for you before the end of this watch.
We have done more incredible things together than something small like this, Capitaine. You just sit back and watch me work.
I'll begin at once!
*ALARM*
Right after we deal with these Morganas...
@BATTLE
These Morganas have horrible timing.
That could be the title of my memoirs one day.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Capitaine, whatever is the matter? Your face looks quite troubled!
That's because I am. I just got a report about another sighting of Despair. Apparently she's up to her old tricks again.
Propaganda broadcasts?
And bombarding coastal regions. She seems to be dodging our patrols and listening in on tactical communications.
This makes it all the more imperative that we work out a new code!

Fields.MenuText: Let's not rush. A barely functional code might be worse than no code.
How's the initial research coming?
Damn right. We need to get this squared away.

Fields.DialogueText: Part of me wants to yell at you for your desire to delay with lives on the line... but I also know that you are right.
Well enough. I'll have a briefing ready for you soon.
That's the spirit Capitaine!
I shall not let Despair hook her talons into me again! Triumph over her will be a personal pleasure, and I look forward to savoring it.
That's a bit of a bloodthirsty look on your face, Triomphant.
Oui... war cannot be a dispassionate affair, Capitaine. But beyond that, with Despair... I fully admit my grudge is personal.
Can't fault you for that. She seems to really be your mirror image to an extent.
She places chains of despair around the necks of the sailors and civilians alike. I swear I will cast her down and break them.
Capitaine? I think I might have discovered another issue with our approach to this code.
Of course you did. Let's hear it, Triomphant.
As I see it, there are two codes in common use. Strategic codes are codes to run the war on, how to order and command your fleets in a whole theater.
On the other hand, a battle code should be fast and efficient to directly order troops in combat... but the world has been adopting hybrid codes that can do both.
This is one major benefit of the Choctaw and other possible linguistic codes. You can use them much more flexibly, even compared to modern encryption.
I'm not sure anything we're doing is the right thing right now... I'm concerned, Capitaine.

Fields.MenuText: Do you think we should abandon the music idea?
I'm concerned as well. I don't want to come up empty-handed, though.
Perhaps we should limit our efforts to one specific form of code.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm not sure. It's the only lead we have at the moment.
Indeed, we cannot fail. We must find a way to press forward.
Perhaps, but I can't help but think the INPF wants a modern code.
I shall redouble my efforts! I won't let everyone down!
I can't help but feel like we're out of our league on a lot of this stuff.
Avoir courage, Capitaine!
Courage isn't what we're lacking, Triomphant.
True, but we must stride forward if we wish to succeed.
@BATTLE
Triomphant? Are you in there? I haven't seen you in ages. Are you all right?
Pardon, Capitaine. I have been... working.
I'd ask if you had slept... but I'll be perfectly honest. I have no idea if you sleep or not.
What a lady does in her chambers is only for a very special person to know, Capitaine, and you are not that person.
Fine, fine, forget I asked. Where the hell have you been?
Well, if you look inside my quarters...
Hell's bells! What the heck is all that paper? It looks like a shell from one of the battleships hit a paper mill in there.
I have been working on a variety of code options. It seems like the nuance always requires yet more paper to accurately map out.

Fields.MenuText: Why are you doing this alone? This type of thing requires a team, and we're supposed to be handling it together.
This really can't be the best way to handle it.
Are you... assigning musical notes to various meanings?

Fields.DialogueText: I thought I could handle it myself. We all have our tasks. I figured this was mine.
Perhaps... but I have yet to find any better way to figure it out.
Oui, I am pleased that you caught on so quickly.
Sigh... I do not think this is going to get us close to smashing Despair again.
I'm starting to get that feeling too. Let's keep going and see if we can figure out a short-term tactical code to stay a step ahead.
Past that, I'm ending this now. We have better things to focus on than this. I need you. The crew needs you. The civilians you've reached with your voice need you.
And I have practical work that's connected to actually running a war. I don't know what joker sent this down to us, but I will be giving them a piece of my mind.
You're going to give up?
We have to know when to stop sinking blood, sweat, and tears into something. Near as I can tell, making this work means we'd need an orchestra in the radio room.
Perhaps one day such things will be possible.
Until then I need to get back to doing my real job and you need to rest. I'm going to message HQ. They can let professionals handle it.
I know some people think Belles are angels or goddesses or whatever, but you're people. Special. Powerful.
But we all have our limits, and doing a job for a large team alone is madness. Thank you, Capitaine. I'm glad you're willing to stand up to me to protect me from myself.
When faced with such pressures it can be easy to forget there are many roads to victory, and not all of them are the right ones to walk.
@BATTLE
You know, Capitaine, for a tactical code, I really think we might be onto something with music. Bugles, whistles including our own bosun's whistle, drums...
All have been used to signal formations of troops with sounds. One of the other Belles was telling me some steppe peoples even used specially carved singing arrows.
Singing arrows? That's a wild idea.
Oui, I thought so as well. But it's quite simple: they're carved a specific way to produce specific sounds in flight. A general will then fire the arrow above his troops to signal.
That sounds about as efficient and effective as I expect out of stories related to the Mongols and their successors.
They were quite efficient, weren't they? Even their brutality served a purpose. Not for pleasure, but to expedite hostilities.

Fields.MenuText: Sounds like we have some possibilities for developing a tactical code mixed with some call signs to identify ships.
We'd have the advantage of quicker evolution, and local groups could use different instruments and sounds.
It's certainly got its limitations, but we can always flip back to normal codes if we need to. That might be messy in the middle of a fight.

Fields.DialogueText: Indeed, that's precisely what I'm working on. It's an initial "songbook," if you will, as well as developing theory of how to quickly "rebuild" the code.
One fleet uses the bosun's whistle, another the bagpipes, another an accordion. It would certainly discourage Morganas from listening to our radio networks.
I believe that's a problem that training can solve. We can do this Capitaine.
Hmm, seems things are looking up. Even if we didn't go in the direction we were hoping for.
Let's save the optimism till we manage to surprise Despair and send her back to whatever hell she crawled out of.
Oui, I am quite looking forward to that moment. Let us not delay more than we have to.
@BATTLE
Bonjour, Capitaine! I have come in my role as chief morale officer to put you on your regularly scheduled break with me.
If it means getting away from the endless paperwork and intelligence reports on Despair I'm more than happy to do so. What's all this?
I have just returned from visiting the various departments. I figured since I was going, I'd bring some fresh fruit and other things I picked up when last we made port.
I saved a few things for us to enjoy as well. This plan of mine seems to has worked out quite well, and celebration is in order for us and our crew.
If you were handing out oranges you'd even be helping fight scurvy.
Let us hope our sailors are better fed than to have to worry about that, Capitaine, but fruit is a beneficial balm that soothes many wounds.

Fields.MenuText: Well, thank you, Triomphant. I certainly appreciate it and I'm sure the crew will too.
Give me a moment. I just want to finish this report and then I'll take a break.
What would you say if I said you resembled an angel of mercy right around now?

Fields.DialogueText: Merci, Capitaine. I want everyone to fight with a happy heart.
Non! You will take a break and you will enjoy yourself. Your work will always be there, Capitaine.
Flattery will get you nowhere... but is appreciated anyway.
*ALARM*
Guess that break is going to have to wait.
We'll just have to make short work of them!
@BATTLE
Capitaine! We're ready for the exercise. Maneuvers will be passed via the radio room using the test code we've prepared.
Assuming everything proceeds smoothly, we shall begin gunnery drills while issuing maneuver commands via the whistle.
I am quite confident in this code, Capitaine, and I am very confident in your ships.
Including yourself, of course.
Especially myself.
*ALARM*
Captain! Enemy ships sighted! They're moving to engage!
Is Despair leading them?
No, Mademoiselle!
Return to your station and we'll get these rude guests sorted out.
@BATTLE
We saw them off rightly, I think, and I have excellent news. The radio rooms did not switch back to our normal communications protocols.
So we got an actual battle test in?
We did indeed, Capitaine! And it performed well for issuing tactical orders.

Fields.MenuText: Well, that'll certainly convince HQ. No proof of concept like success.
Remind me to have a word with the radio room about suspending testing protocols if the test is interrupted by combat.
Huh, I thought that shrill noise I heard was just shell fire.

Fields.DialogueText: Of course, a victory is everyone's child, while defeat is an orphan. HQ will want their share of our success.
That might be a good idea. It certainly worked out, but imagine if we'd been testing some other new piece of equipment.
Well, it was also shell fire, but I can see how they'd blend together from a distance.
Still, another day where we can drink the ambrosia of victory. Such a day is always good, no matter what chaos happens in battle.
I'll drink to that... if we had anything to drink. Maybe once I'm off duty.
I know you're out there. Show yourself.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
I'm getting frustrated, Capitaine... Despair is out there. I can feel her, but I can't find her. How hard can it be to find a fleet of warships? Merde!
Calm down. We're patrolling more aggressively and we've been taking down various Morgana fleets in the area.
Yes... but Despair eludes us. I honestly think she might be trying to play games. To make me... despair... of ever finding her. Pardon me, I couldn't think of a better word.
Well you don't seem to be despairing to me.
I'm not. I'm furious.
It might not be the emotion she desires, but it's still throwing you off your game, which can play right into her hands.
You're right. I'm not sure that's going to change my attitude in wanting to find her. I still owe her more pain for what she did to France.

Fields.MenuText: Are you sure you're not taking this a bit too personally?
I can see how love and hate are two sides of the same coin. When you talk about Despair, you're just so passionate about wrecking her face.
I know how you feel. We're going to pay her back triple.

Fields.DialogueText: Perhaps I am, but she made this a personal fight. I am going to finish it.
Non, Capitaine! Love and hate are not two sides of the same coin. The opposite of love is indifference. Not hatred.
I shall hold you to that promise, mon ami.
I wonder... she seems to like civilian targets. We've been keeping her tempo... perhaps we could turn the tables on her.
That's a rather evil look on your face, Triomphant. What evil are you planning?
No evil, Capitaine. Just victory. I need to go look into some things. I'll find you later.
I'd say I have a bad feeling about this... but it's clearly going to be bad for someone who richly deserves it.
What's that noise? It sounds like... Triomphant? Almost sounds like she's on the radio...
...and that all peoples of the world shall rise up to cast down these foul creatures of the sea! Take heart! We are humanity's sword and shield and we shall not abandon you.
Oh, Capitaine! I didn't notice you come in. I was doing some recording.
Not broadcasting? Interesting. What are you up to?
Nothing yet. I need you to sign this requisition form for some combat engineers to come into this area for a little building project.
Do I get to know what you're up to yet?
Soon. Hopefully. I need to confirm I can put everything together first.
You're being mysterious again. What's this other form?
Special equipment for the combat engineers to install with everything else.
Fine, I'll sign it.
You're being quite helpful today, Capitaine. Are you feeling well? You're being a little too cooperative.

Fields.MenuText: I know I can trust you at this point, even if you're being mysterious.
It's easier to cut to the chase. I don't need you to hound me until I give in like your radio broadcaster friend.
Like there's even a point trying to stop you.

Fields.DialogueText: Don't worry, Capitaine. The mystery will be even more fun for drawing it out a bit.
So I've finally gotten you trained properly. Wonderful!
You really do know me too well, Capitaine.
I'll be off to handle these requisitions and plan out the briefing for my mission!
All right, all right, but I want to know what gives with all these the second you're able to say.
Of course, Capitaine. You'll be first to see the whole picture besides me.
@BATTLE
... Looks like I might have to squint through gunsmoke, though.
All right, Triomphant, we're here. What am I looking at?
What do you see on that island over there, Capitaine?
Couple piers, a mix of buildings of corrugated metal, looks like a radio tower... is there an INPF forward base in this area? It's not on any of the charts.
There isn't a base here, for the INPF or anyone else. There is only a remotely operated radio transmitter and a bunch of shells of buildings.
Everything you see is more or less an optical illusion, like a Hollywood movie set.
This is what you got to me sign off on? What's the po... oh. You wanted to set up some bait. Bait Despair herself couldn't possibly ignore.
She's been toying with my emotions by evading us. Trying to frustrate me. Anger me. Distract me. So now I'm going to turn the tables.
She will come to us. We need to continue to engage fleets in the area. I will arrange for some broadcasts to happen during battle, accidentally revealing this "base."
Barring some possible complications, like Despair tracking the signal early, we should be able to lure her in and destroy her. Again.

Fields.MenuText: This war would be going a lot more smoothly if the Morganas would be polite enough to stay sunk.
We really don't want them to turn up early, but we can't be moving the signal around too much either.
We could leave a small team with a radar station inland. They'd give us some early warning if the Morganas break the horizon.

Fields.DialogueText: It is quite rude that they don't have the common decency to stay dead.
We'll manage it properly Capitaine, we just have to follow the plan I've laid out.
I considered that, but I don't want to risk their lives... they'd be quite exposed, and what if we don't make it in time?
Victory will come this blow, I can taste it. We shall make Despair know despair.
We ought to be getting close...
Oui, Capitaine. Not so many obstacles left in our way...
@BATTLE
Tu voulais me voir, Capitaine?
I did. We have some reports from our operational area and the nearby ones. The Morganas have gotten all kinds of stirred up. Seems your plan is working.
It is a very strong transmitter and in a very good position. It can even drown out Despair's dreadful voice.
They've even been leaving settlements alone and ignoring more civilian shipping than usual. They're on the hunt for any ships with neutrality stripes.
I have more or less slapped her across the mouth with a white glove, Capitaine. Of course Despair would come for me.

Fields.MenuText: That is the plan, after all.
Let's just hope we haven't bit off more than we can chew. I'm worried about some of the reports of the Morganas looking... different.
Hmph. Just so long as we don't lose the duel we started.

Fields.DialogueText: Mais bien sûr. Let us hope she sticks her neck into the noose as we desire.
I have been feeling it... the other Belles, too. Our foes grow stronger, so we must grow stronger as well. Slinking into the shadows will not save us.
Ayez confiance en moi, capitaine. I am Triomphant. And so shall we all be.
Capitaine, I... hmm... hold that thought. We have guests.
Captain! Enemy squadron on the horizon!
God damn it, they just can't quit. Action stations!
@BATTLE
Sir, we have a Morgana sighting.
Sound the alarm.
@BATTLE
Sir, Ma'am. That was the last of the messages we were instructed to transmit.
They almost certainly received it. Despair has been shown to listen to such things, and I'm sure her ships are listening too.
That will be all. Dismissed.
So the bait has been laid, the trap prepared... Now we must wait for the arrival of the prey to end our little morality play.
I've already given the order to make flank speed for the crucial area.
Good. I know this will not stop her, but I cannot let her have her way. We must defeat her.
I know, don't worry. I'll be right beside you the whole way. As many times as we need to knock Despair's teeth in.
Every Belle should be so lucky to have such a supportive capitaine.

Fields.MenuText: What's the point of power if you can't abuse it for your friends?
Your interests in this case align with the INPF's and the overall war effort. Even if I didn't support you, it'd be foolish not to.
You're talking like I could somehow stop you again.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm glad to be in a position to benefit from your corruption, Capitaine. I'll never breathe a word of it to anyone.
So professional, Capitaine. You know you don't have to set everything you do up for scrutiny by lawyers.
Hehe... I really do have you properly trained. Make sure you don't die, mon ami. It would be far too much work to break in a new capitaine.
Let's see how long it takes for Despair to take our bait.
*BOOM*
There was never any hope! All shall be subsumed by us. Even if you succeed, there is no peace waiting for you. Only the deathly peace we grant shall last!
I think we've heard quite enough of that. Turn that horrid noise off, s'il vous plaît?
Damn, sounds like Despair's taken our bait. Hard.
She has indeed. She didn't even scout the area properly. Simply started shelling the island near at random. The scouts on the far side of the island we're using as cover...
...say that she has only just now started shelling our fake supply base, and they started shelling the island some thirty minutes ago.

Fields.MenuText: Sounds like now is the perfect time to go and welcome our guest of honor.
I almost want the sailor to turn the radio on again. She's going to be furious when we engage her fleet from behind.

Fields.DialogueText: Let us go and be good hosts, then!
It would be entertaining... possibly even worth recording for personal amusement later, but I'd rather not listen to that harpy's voice any more than I have to.
Well then, sailors, let's close the noose.
XO, status?
All ships standing by.
Pass the order. All ships move to engage. Bring us out around the island at flank speed. Let's not waste the element of surprise.
There is nothing to fear! Only victory to gain!
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: What were we so worried about in the first place?

Fields.DialogueText: Ne soyez pas complaisant. Slowing them down and misdirecting them is one thing. Destroying them is another.
Still working, Capitaine?
Some of us have to do the reports for things like engaging Morgana fleets, you know.
Eh bien, il est temps de faire une pause. I snuck a case of champagne into the last supply budget and have had it distributed equally. This bottle is ours.
I'll ignore a well-intentioned misappropriation of INPF funds.
As a wise capitaine I know once said: what use is power if I cannot abuse it for my friends?
That Captain sounds like a smartass. Maybe you should have found a better one.
Non. I am a very lucky Belle to have found a Capitaine such as you.
I thought the Belles had some innate "sense" that lead them to their Captains.
In a manner of speaking, but even if we can sense the attitudes and qualities we admire in a person, we cannot predict the future.
That'd be an interesting skill to develop. Give it a try? You know, if you come up with some free time.
I shall see what I can do. But to finish, just because you are a good and worthy capitaine does not mean we shall instantly be friends, or be friends at all.
So I am especially glad that we are. It makes sharing in victories like this one all the more luxurious.

Fields.MenuText: I'll drink to that.
All the more reason to get out and earn more laurels for our pile.

Fields.DialogueText: A glass for you, and a glass for me...
Our entire crew shall be wearing them by war's end!

Fields.MenuText: I'd never want you as an enemy.

Fields.DialogueText: Hate, love, coins, and all that. We fight as fiercely as we love!
Nothing like a little tidying up, is there?
After Despair, these Morganas are nothing to us!
@BATTLE
